content: Here is a response on Ingram's page ""USEFUL IDIOT" WATCH... Memo to Meghan McCain: Enjoy the media coverage while it lasts, but know you're being used. You are the flavor of the month in left-wing media land because you are a Republican bashing the GOP. Likewise, your dad is most popular among the same people when he is slamming his Republican brethren in full-blown "maverick" fashion. At least he backs up his views with a lifetime of sacrifice and public service. What is Ms. McCain's own political, business, or real-world experience that lends credibility to her argument that the GOP needs to "moderate" (read: abandon its core principles)? " "http://www.lauraingraham.com/" Seems to me she is now displaying how the republican party really felt about John McCain. It's too bad John flip flopped over to the far right, I could have voted for him had he stayed where he was and didn't put on a show for the Reps.

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: LMAO!!! I am really starting to like this gal. "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/03/16/meghan-mccain-on-the-view_n_175319.html" I can't stand Laura Ingraham (I put her right DOWN there with Rush) and I am glad Megan put her in her place. If this woman ever decides to run...she may have my vote..she has more guts than Palin (and good looks) ever dreamed of. Interesting reading the level of the "debate." Ingraham seems to think that calling her fat is the beginning end end of discussion... quote: INGRAHAM (mocking): Ok, Meghan. Do you think that anyone would be talking to you if you weren't kind of cute and you weren't the daughter of John McCain? Or do you just think that they would just think that you were just another Valley Girl gone awry? MADDOW: You picked a fight with somebody who's definitely going to fight back. MCCAIN: Yeah. Well, if it was, you know, if it was too hot in the kitchen, I'd get out. I know what I'm doing and I know that I'm creating, she probably will respond, she already has, but I'm sure she'll respond harder, but this dialogue should take place. It should. I think that you know, often times and I think it's relevant because I am a Republican. I still consider myself a Republican and that's why it's relevant because I'm someone within the party. INGRAHAM (mocking): How long before she totally abandons the Daily Beast and makes it official at the Huffington Post? MCCAIN: And I think there's an extreme on both parties and I hate extreme. I don't understand. I have friends that are the most radically conservative and radically liberal people possibly ever and we all get along. We can find a middle ground. INGRAHAM (mocking): Ok, I was really hoping that I was going to get that role in the Real World, but then I realized that, well, they don't like plus-sized models. They only like the women who look a certain way. And on this 50th anniversary of Barbie, I really have something to say. Kind of pathetic, when you're reduced to making your political point by celebrating Barbie, (Barbie? She's celebrating Barbie?) and calling someone names. Dave

content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: Meghan has sampled the lime light and now she wants more..... this is what it's all about, nothing more. I don't believe that it's appropriate for someone like myself to give the Republican Party advice. So I will simply note that I respect John McCain. I respect Ron Paul and Bob Barr, Chuck Hegal and other Republicans. I have no respect for Rush or Savage or Ingraham. While I'm not a typical voter, I suspect that the Democrats are joining you in wishing Ms. McCain to get off the public airwaves, so that they can continue to celebrate the new face of the Republican Party - Rush, Ingraham, Coulter, etc... Those who like Rush and company have absolutely no idea of what I'm talking about, or even what my point is. I suspect a Conservative like crakerjack will get the message. You can draw your own conclusions. Dave

title: Meghan McCain - Laura Ingraham Can Kiss My Fat Ass

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Here is a response on Ingram's page ""USEFUL IDIOT" WATCH... Memo to Meghan McCain: Enjoy the media coverage while it lasts, but know you're being used. You are the flavor of the month in left-wing media land because you are a Republican bashing the GOP. Likewise, your dad is most popular among the same people when he is slamming his Republican brethren in full-blown "maverick" fashion. At least he backs up his views with a lifetime of sacrifice and public service. What is Ms. McCain's own political, business, or real-world experience that lends credibility to her argument that the GOP needs to "moderate" (read: abandon its core principles)? " "http://www.lauraingraham.com/" Seems to me she is now displaying how the republican party really felt about John McCain. It's too bad John flip flopped over to the far right, I could have voted for him had he stayed where he was and didn't put on a show for the Reps. I believe the point Meghan McCain is making is that for people in her age category individuals like Coulter, Limbaugh and Ingraham are essentially irrelevant. Survey after survey has demonstrated that a substantial number of those under 40 do not like Limbaugh. Who can blame them, why should they pay any heed to some blathering fool who is so obviously incapable of speaking to them. The same is true of Coulter and Ingraham - neither has a message designed to pique the interest of the younger crowd. If the Republican Party was led by individuals with insight and vision (like that will ever happen in this life!!) they would discount the Coulters and embrace people like Meghan McCain. This is not to attempt to argue that she should be elevated to a leadership position (although all things considered what harm could it do?) but rather that unless conservatives broaden their message they should expect their time on the back benches to be long term and possibly permanent.

At least he backs up his views with a lifetime of sacrifice and public service. What is Ms. McCain's own political, business, or real-world experience that lends credibility to her argument that the GOP needs to "moderate" (read: abandon its core principles)? " "http://www.lauraingraham.com/" Seems to me she is now displaying how the republican party really felt about John McCain. It's too bad John flip flopped over to the far right, I could have voted for him had he stayed where he was and didn't put on a show for the Reps.
reply: I believe the point Meghan McCain is making is that for people in her age category individuals like Coulter, Limbaugh and Ingraham are essentially irrelevant. Survey after survey has demonstrated that a substantial number of those under 40 do not like Limbaugh. Who can blame them, why should they pay any heed to some blathering fool who is so obviously incapable of speaking to them. The same is true of Coulter and Ingraham - neither has a message designed to pique the interest of the younger crowd. If the Republican Party was led by individuals with insight and vision (like that will ever happen in this life!!) they would discount the Coulters and embrace people like Meghan McCain. content: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: Guts is standing up to a left wing media attack with poise and dignity. That is what I admire most about the governor. Since when is CBS News the left wing media? Some time now. Perhaps you should read Bernard Goldeberg's book Bias in which he outlined left wing bias in tne media. By the way, he is a former CBS newsman. a. Sumner Redstone, the CEO of Viacom, the parent company of CBS, was a Bush supporter. A quote from him: "I look at the election from what's good for Viacom. I vote for what's good for Viacom. I vote, today, Viacom. I don't want to denigrate Kerry, but from a Viacom standpoint, the election of a Republican administration is a better deal. Because the Republican administration has stood for many things we believe in, deregulation and so on. The Democrats are not bad people...But from a Viacom standpoint, we believe the election of a Republican administration is better for our company." "http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=110005669" b. If CBS were a "liberal" news outlet, Dan Rather would have never been fired. c. CBS refused to run anti-Bush campaign ads by MoveOn.org in 2004. The corporate media is hardly liberal - that's a myth.

Who can blame them, why should they pay any heed to some blathering fool who is so obviously incapable of speaking to them. The same is true of Coulter and Ingraham - neither has a message designed to pique the interest of the younger crowd. If the Republican Party was led by individuals with insight and vision (like that will ever happen in this life!!) they would discount the Coulters and embrace people like Meghan McCain. This is not to attempt to argue that she should be elevated to a leadership position (although all things considered what harm could it do?) but rather that unless conservatives broaden their message they should expect their time on the back benches to be long term and possibly permanent. I suspect Ingraham and Limbaugh make more money than all the posters on mil.com. They laugh all the way to the banks while bashing dumb liberals and have bigger followings than any lib And now that we see how confused Obama is lately all the dummies that voted for him must shurly be crying rivers in their pillows every night! Lots of people have gotten rich in America by preying on suckers - and a country of 300 million people will likely have a huge number of them.

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: LMAO!!! I am really starting to like this gal. "http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/03/16/meghan-mccain-on-the-view_n_175319.html" I can't stand Laura Ingraham (I put her right DOWN there with Rush) and I am glad Megan put her in her place. If this woman ever decides to run...she may have my vote..she has more guts than Palin (and good looks) ever dreamed of. Interesting reading the level of the "debate." Ingraham seems to think that calling her fat is the beginning end end of discussion... quote: INGRAHAM (mocking): Ok, Meghan. Do you think that anyone would be talking to you if you weren't kind of cute and you weren't the daughter of John McCain? Or do you just think that they would just think that you were just another Valley Girl gone awry? MADDOW: You picked a fight with somebody who's definitely going to fight back. MCCAIN: Yeah. Well, if it was, you know, if it was too hot in the kitchen, I'd get out. I know what I'm doing and I know that I'm creating, she probably will respond, she already has, but I'm sure she'll respond harder, but this dialogue should take place. It should. I think that you know, often times and I think it's relevant because I am a Republican. I still consider myself a Republican and that's why it's relevant because I'm someone within the party. INGRAHAM (mocking): How long before she totally abandons the Daily Beast and makes it official at the Huffington Post? MCCAIN: And I think there's an extreme on both parties and I hate extreme. I don't understand. I have friends that are the most radically conservative and radically liberal people possibly ever and we all get along. We can find a middle ground. INGRAHAM (mocking): Ok, I was really hoping that I was going to get that role in the Real World, but then I realized that, well, they don't like plus-sized models. They only like the women who look a certain way. And on this 50th anniversary of Barbie, I really have something to say. Kind of pathetic, when you're reduced to making your political point by celebrating Barbie, (Barbie? She's celebrating Barbie?) and calling someone names. Dave

"http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/03/16/meghan-mccain-on-the-view_n_175319.html" I can't stand Laura Ingraham (I put her right DOWN there with Rush) and I am glad Megan put her in her place. content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: Meghan has sampled the lime light and now she wants more..... this is what it's all about, nothing more. I don't believe that it's appropriate for someone like myself to give the Republican Party advice. So I will simply note that I respect John McCain. I respect Ron Paul and Bob Barr, Chuck Hegal and other Republicans. I have no respect for Rush or Savage or Ingraham. While I'm not a typical voter, I suspect that the Democrats are joining you in wishing Ms. McCain to get off the public airwaves, so that they can continue to celebrate the new face of the Republican Party - Rush, Ingraham, Coulter, etc... Those who like Rush and company have absolutely no idea of what I'm talking about, or even what my point is. I suspect a Conservative like crakerjack will get the message. You can draw your own conclusions. Dave

Sumner Redstone, the CEO of Viacom, the parent company of CBS, was a Bush supporter. A quote from him: "I look at the election from what's good for Viacom. I vote for what's good for Viacom. I vote, today, Viacom. I don't want to denigrate Kerry, but from a Viacom standpoint, the election of a Republican administration is a better deal. Because the Republican administration has stood for many things we believe in, deregulation and so on. The Democrats are not bad people...But from a Viacom standpoint, we believe the election of a Republican administration is better for our company." "http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=110005669" b. If CBS were a "liberal" news outlet, Dan Rather would have never been fired. c. CBS refused to run anti-Bush campaign ads by MoveOn.org in 2004. The corporate media is hardly liberal - that's a myth.
quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by scooter_mech: Guts is standing up to a left wing media attack with poise and dignity. That is what I admire most about the governor. Since when is CBS News the left wing media? Some time now. Perhaps you should read Bernard Goldeberg's book Bias in which he outlined left wing bias in tne media. By the way, he is a former CBS newsman.
reply: a. Sumner Redstone, the CEO of Viacom, the parent company of CBS, was a Bush supporter. A quote from him: "I look at the election from what's good for Viacom. I vote for what's good for Viacom. I vote, today, Viacom. I don't want to denigrate Kerry, but from a Viacom standpoint, the election of a Republican administration is a better deal. Because the Republican administration has stood for many things we believe in, deregulation and so on. The Democrats are not bad people...But from a Viacom standpoint, we believe the election of a Republican administration is better for our company." "http://www.opinionjournal.com/extra/?id=110005669" b. If CBS were a "liberal" news outlet, Dan Rather would have never been fired. c. CBS refused to run anti-Bush campaign ads by MoveOn.org in 2004. The corporate media is hardly liberal - that's a myth.
title: Meghan McCain - Laura Ingraham Can Kiss My Fat Ass

content: quote: Originally posted by EAG154: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: Here is a response on Ingram's page ""USEFUL IDIOT" WATCH... Memo to Meghan McCain: Enjoy the media coverage while it lasts, but know you're being used. You are the flavor of the month in left-wing media land because you are a Republican bashing the GOP. Likewise, your dad is most popular among the same people when he is slamming his Republican brethren in full-blown "maverick" fashion. At least he backs up his views with a lifetime of sacrifice and public service. What is Ms. McCain's own political, business, or real-world experience that lends credibility to her argument that the GOP needs to "moderate" (read: abandon its core principles)? " "http://www.lauraingraham.com/" Seems to me she is now displaying how the republican party really felt about John McCain. It's too bad John flip flopped over to the far right, I could have voted for him had he stayed where he was and didn't put on a show for the Reps. I believe the point Meghan McCain is making is that for people in her age category individuals like Coulter, Limbaugh and Ingraham are essentially irrelevant. Survey after survey has demonstrated that a substantial number of those under 40 do not like Limbaugh. Who can blame them, why should they pay any heed to some blathering fool who is so obviously incapable of speaking to them. The same is true of Coulter and Ingraham - neither has a message designed to pique the interest of the younger crowd. If the Republican Party was led by individuals with insight and vision (like that will ever happen in this life!!) they would discount the Coulters and embrace people like Meghan McCain. This is not to attempt to argue that she should be elevated to a leadership position (although all things considered what harm could it do?) but rather that unless conservatives broaden their message they should expect their time on the back benches to be long term and possibly permanent. I suspect Ingraham and Limbaugh make more money than all the posters on mil.com. They laugh all the way to the banks while bashing dumb liberals and have bigger followings than any lib And now that we see how confused Obama is lately all the dummies that voted for him must shurly be crying rivers in their pillows every night! Lots of people have gotten rich in America by preying on suckers - and a country of 300 million people will likely have a huge number of them.
